references: We consider an AirComp system with Mğ‘€M edge devices, each with a single antenna connected to the PS that is equipped with Nğ‘N antennas. Multiple edge devices are allowed to transmit simultaneously on the same channel. The number of edge devices participating in the model update in each communication round is limited in order to minimize the distortion error and maximize the testing model performance. Assume the maximum number of selected devices for transmitting in each round is Kğ¾K under AirComp[7]. The main notations used in the paper are summarized in Table I.

The corresponding time complexity is summarized in Table II.

references: In this section, we present the performance of federated learning under AirComp with different user scheduling schemes. The channel parameters are given as follows. There are M=1000ğ‘€1000M=1000 users uniformly distributed in a disk region with a cell size of 500500500 m. The transmit signal to noise ratio Pâ€‹0Ïƒ2ğ‘ƒ0superscriptğœ2\frac{P0}{\sigma^{2}} is fixed at 424242 dB, channel path loss exponent is Î±=3ğ›¼3\alpha=3. The number of antennas at PS is N=4ğ‘4N=4. In each communication round, the channel vector keeps constant for the same user while it varies across different users and/or different communication rounds. We further have K=10ğ¾10K=10 and W=20ğ‘Š20W=20. The learning task is trained by using the MNIST (Modified National Institute of Standards and Technology) dataset [13] with a fully connected neural network called LeNet-300-100, where the first hidden layer consists of 300300300 neurons and the second layer consists of 100100100 neurons. The hyperparameters are summarized in Table III. The learning stages are divided into two phases, namely training phase and testing phase. Similarly, the dataset also split into two parts, 90%percent9090\% of them are training set and the rest are the testing set. The testing accuracy is used to evaluate the learning performance. To make the proposed scheduling schemes more convincing, non-i.i.d data [14] is used here, i.e., every user has a varying data size and distribution.
